title: Friday, 4th March, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am

PM

11:01 am

PM

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz41vjEvBkz

PM

The Wentworth golf dispute could drive investors into the rough

11:02 am
PM

Prospects for growing business links between the UK and China have never been brighter. Last year’s visit to Britain by President Xi Jinping was greeted warmly on both sides and has led to renewed interest in cementing the ties between our two nations. Ahead of Mr Xi’s visit, David Cameron, prime minister, said trade and investment between China and Britain can benefit from a “golden era” in their bilateral relations.
Set against that backdrop, the recent dispute involving members of Wentworth golf club, who object to Reignwood’s plans to invest millions of pounds to return it to past glories, is very disappointing. Not only is it based on a misunderstanding of what we are trying to achieve, it misses the wider point about the need for China and the UK to work more closely together in order to bring more investment here. The dispute risks sending the wrong message to other foreign businesses about the climate for investment.

PM

Oped from Ni Songhua

PM

It's quite illiquid. We've had twice the daily average traded already this morning.

IE. 1.5m shares.

11:13 am
BE

The illiquidity and the pre-results-ness led us to be cautious about the rumour -- though to be clear we didn't have as much info as Ben, and we've no opinion on what he's written.

BE

For the sake of filling space, here's Jefferies on BBA's results yesterday.

BE

Post the transformational Landmark deal, Signature's strength through FY15
is for us key in today's results. As too is confirmation that Landmark continued
"good growth" last year in line with expectations & that additional revenue
synergies have already been identified. There's an unexpected positive in news
that ASIG has attracted external interest. Further noise from ERO dulls all this
a little, but that unit is being diluted to the periphery of this group.
FY15 results include group PBT/EPS at $170m/20c, compared with JEFe at $174m/20c and
Factset consensus at $172m/20c. Versus our divisional forecasts, Flight Support was $4.2m
ahead though included a $4.3m non-cash 2H gain we had not foreseen (linked to ASIG's
purchase of its JV partner's stake in ASIG Panama). This was offset by Aftermarket falling
$8.5m behind our model. With Legacy described as "solid" and "as anticipated", ERO is the
disappointment here. Pro-forma net debt/EBITDA was 3.5x (as it has long been guided to
be) and the FY DPS has been increased 5% yoy (rights issue adjusted) to 13.5c. That delivers
the group commitment made when announcing the Landmark transaction last September
to continue the 5% yoy interim DPS growth for the FY (rights issue adjusted basis). We also
see DPS growth as reflecting group confidence in its "good deleveraging profile."

11:14 am
BE

Signature's strength. FBO is the future of this group (over 80% of pro-forma divisional
EBIT contributions including the targeted $35m synergies). Two aspects of Signature's FY15
performance are encouraging: (1) Signature's organic revenues grew 4% over the year,
convincingly stronger than B&GA movements at +1% in the US and -3% in Europe over the
period. (2) Signature's organic growth accelerated from +3% over 1H to +4% for the full
year (implies +5% 2H) despite no change in movement trends 1H to 2H in either of the two
key regions. Flight Support EBIT, driven by Signature, advanced 19% yoy.
There's further opportunities in the Landmark purchase beyond the $35m cost
savings targeted. Though not quantified, the group is already flagging further opportunities
from "enhanced revenue management" (the acquisition only completed last month).
FBO disposal process to plan. Management report "good progress" and pleasing
interest in the six FBOs it agreed to sell as part of the regulatory approval to buy Landmark.
"Significant" inbound interest in ASIG. The unit fell to less than 5% of Flight Support's
FY15 EBIT. With its focus of servicing commercial airlines, as BBA becomes more B&GA
focused post Landmark, ASIG's role in the group is increasingly less obvious. We expect
news that management are reviewing "value maximisation alternatives" in response to
"significant" external interest in the division to be widely welcomed by the market.

BE

Still challenging for ERO that drove Aftermarket profits down $12m yoy in 1H15 and
down $18m yoy in 2H. Positive ERO dynamics looking forward are: no repeat of the 1H15
costs incurred to compensate for the operational challenges stemming from the footprint
rationalisation issues (we assumed c$14m at the time) and cost saving plans announced
today (benefit not disclosed but the related $5m exceptional cash cost points to limited
scale). In the other direction: the competitive 2H15 market conditions have to lap through
for ERO and the $40m of FY15 engine trading revenue can't be relied on to repeat.
Consensus expectations. It's a challenge to fully understand the basis of FY16 consensus
(consolidation assumptions for Landmark, inclusion/exclusion of the six FBOs due for
disposal), but we expect that, as for us, ERO may disappoint the wider market within the
FY15 performance. Crudely, that perhaps may prompt low to mid single-digit underlying
percentage downgrades to consensus FY16 forecasts. Worth noting BBA has said that the
six FBOs due to be sold contributed $16.1m EBITDA in FY14.

BE

And Investec.

11:15 am
BE

FY15 results were around 1% ahead of our expectations, with a strong performance at Signature more than offsetting shortfalls elsewhere. While we make no substantial changes to our forecasts, the strong Signature performance and positive outlook further enhances our confidence in the group’s prospects. We also believe potential revenue synergies from the Landmark acquisition are substantial, and may provide further upside to our forecasts. BUY recommendation retained, TP increased to 235p (from 225p).

FY Results: At the group level, operating profit was around 1% ahead of our forecasts. Divisionally, Flight Support was 1.8% ahead of our expectations, while Aftermarket Services continued its downward trend, with operating profit 7.6% lower than our expectations. Signature had the strongest performance within the group, with organic revenue growth slightly strengthening in Q4, despite a sluggish market. As expected, ERO appears to be weak, with inefficiencies resulting from the ongoing footprint rationalisation.
Outlook: Despite recent market concerns, Signature (c.80% of group profits going forwards) is continuing to trade well. We are particularly excited by the emerging revenue synergy opportunities at Signature, and expect the Landmark acquisition to significantly increase the value of BBA’s FBO portfolio to customers. We note that operating leverage to price increases is likely to be near-100%. Management expect FY16 ND/EBITDA of around 3.0x (our forecast imply 3.3x), from a pro-forma FY15 level of 3.5x, this is a lower level of leverage than we had previously expected, and should reduce the group’s balance sheet sensitivity to a macroeconomic softening. The likelihood of a disposal of ASIG appears to have increased following third-party interest, which we believe could further reduce leverage by around 0.2x.
Valuation & Recommendation: BBA trades on 10.7x FY17e p/e and 4.9% dividend yield. This valuation appears to us to imply a material weakening in BBA’s outlook going forwards, despite the business so far showing strong resilience to a softening macroeconomic backdrop. In light of this, we retain our BUY recommendation, and increase our DCF-based TP to 235p.

BE

And of course, if there's a reason for either the predator or the prey to put out a statement, I'm sure everyone's aware of their obligations.

11:15 am
PM

Let me get some ECB stuff up

PM

People are really expecting action from Draghi

PM

Let's start with some Reinhard Cluse -- UBS

11:16 am
PM

Q: Is more monetary stimulus justified?
Yes: HICP inflation dropped back to -0.2% y/y in February (from 0.3% in Jan) while core inflation
eased to 0.7% y/y (from 0.9%). Longer-term Inflation expectations have taken another knock, with
5y5y inflation forwards little above 1.4%. Export-orientated sentiment indicators have softened.
Concerns have increased that Eurozone credit conditions might have started to tighten in early 2016.
Uncertainty about external conditions, above all in China and the EM block, remains high.

PM

Q: What choices for more monetary stimulus does the ECB have?
QE: The ECB will consider an increase in its monthly asset purchases (currently €60bn); a widening in
the pool of eligible assets; and a lengthening in QE beyond March 2017. Interest rates: The Bank
might cut the deposit rate, currently at -0.3%. Liquidity: The ECB might add more liquidity, by
extending the TLTRO programme, launching a new LTRO, or extending the "full allotment mode".

PM

Q: Will the ECB's policy be successful?
Measured against its inflation target of "below but close to 2%", the ECB is struggling. Inflation has
been well below the target over the last 3 years and we expect it to undershoot the target in 2016/17
as well, although we expect inflation to pick up from zero (or negative values) in H1 2016 to 0.9% by
end-2016 and 1.7% by end-2017. A lot will depend on oil prices. Longer term, returning inflation
back to the target in a consistent fashion will depend crucially on Europe's ability to enact fiscal and
structural reforms, which will strengthen domestic demand – it cannot be achieved by the ECB alone.

11:17 am
PM

Key sumary...

PM

We expect the ECB to increase its monthly asset purchases by at least €10bn (from €60bn) on
10 March and cut the deposit rate by 10bps from -0.3%, probably with a tiered structure. The
ECB might well include corporate bonds into its asset purchases, but not bank bonds, we think. We
expect the ECB to keep some of its powder dry and reconsider the end of its QE programme (currently
March 2017) and tapering at a later stage.

BE

(@roddy1234: I'm treating all these questions are rhetorical solely because I don't have a scooby.)

11:17 am
PM

Specifically on neg rates...

PM

Tricky choices: Deposit rate cuts
The ECB has made it clear that it is considering another cut to its deposit rate,
which in the ECB's view would amplify the transmission of its QE and liquidity
policies. The ECB will also count on the negative impact that a deposit rate cut
would likely have on the exchange rate of the EUR. Last but not least, if the ECB
were to cut the deposit rate, it would also widen the universe of negative yielding
bonds it can purchase under its QE programme. After all, the ECB has decided that
it will not buy bonds with a yield below the (negative) deposit rate.

PM

However, recent months have shown how much of a burden negative deposit
rates constitute to the (perceived) profitability of the banking sector. Against this
background, another deposit rate cut would likely increase the headwinds to the
banking sector.
Our base case scenario implies that the ECB will deliver a 10bps deposit rate cut to
-0.4%. However, in order to cushion the fallout on banks' profitability, we believe
the ECB might consider a tiered reduction in the deposit rate where it sets
different depo rates for different levels of excess reserves (relative to required
reserves) or where it charges a lower rate for new reserves while leaving the
deposit rate on hold reserves untouched (or reducing it by less).

11:18 am

PM

Porter from Credit Suisse

11:18 am
BE

Go on then.

PM

Always worth a read

PM

He's talking about the Draghi Put

11:18 am
PM

The Draghi put and corporates
We think the rally we have seen is not just a result of the Draghi put, but also a market that
has become too bearish on the world economy.
But we are buying dips, not chasing rallies. With any luck, given current levels, the 10
March might give one. Short of that, we think there are still opportunities, particularly in
subordinated financials.

PM

We have talked a lot about our disagreement with the market on the economy, most recently
in Put your gloves on. It is based on our view that there is no US recession developing. But
we need to be modest here; the track record of forecasters of any stripe actually forecasting
US recessions is discouraging. Our view that one will be avoided remains grounded in our
view of US corporate profits, as outlined in the 2016 Global Outlook.
In this piece, we focus on the Draghi put, following on from our earlier collaboration with
our economics colleagues. Additionally, there is an emerging consensus that investors
should “buy the rumour, sell the fact” on the 10 March meeting. We are in buy on dips
mode and we emphasize our view that disappointment or profit-taking on 10 March would
mark the sort of dip we are looking for.
It may happen; if we look at the track record of the BoJ at a similar stage of dealing with
the zero bound by extending it into private markets (via ETF1
s), extensions of asset
purchases have a mixed track record.

PM

In a letter published on 1 March, Draghi wrote that “work is being carried out to ensure that
all the technical conditions are in place to make the full range of policy options available
for implementation, if needed.”
What needs stressing is that for the ECB, that range is enormous. It has its own internal
political constraints, which the market often pays serious attention to. And we are all used
to the Article 123 mantra, which defines what it cannot do. But apart from the direct
sovereign financing prohibited under said 123, when the politics allow a 2/3 majority on the
GC, the ECB can do pretty well anything. This is based on Article 20 of the governing
protocol: “The Governing Council may, by a majority of two thirds of the votes cast, decide

11:19 am
PM

upon the use of such other operational methods of monetary control as it sees fit,
respecting Article 2.” We read this as being incredibly broad, with the constraint being the
politics and the practicality, not the law.
The politics are a matter of incentive, as we saw during the sovereign crisis, and we think
the incentive structure made itself clear again during February. In 2010/12, faced with an
existential threat, the ECB was Draghi. In February, we suspect we were rapidly headed in
the same direction helped by the economics discussed above. In any case, the market
abruptly started pricing systematic risk (evidence, the iTraxx Senior).
Looking at the performance of an ENEL bond of roughly the same duration vs the LEI
euro shows clearly how the ECB on 2 July directly and effectively targeted the
peripheral / systemic risk narrative that took hold on 2 July against the backdrop of the
renewed Greek crisis.

NC

Negative deposit rates are effectively another tax on banks. This depresses equity prices, which makes it even harder to raise new permanent capital. Quite likely to have the opposite effect of that intended.

PM

I will try and usual place this -- so you can see the charts

11:19 am
PM

We realize this is at odds with the BoJ chart above and perhaps the combined lesson is
that targeted, specific, intervention in private markets has more hope of success than
using those markets as a tool of macro policy. We think the nature of recent ECB
comments puts us squarely in the former situation. And of course, the real burden of the
above chart is that this is a central bank that already buys corporates; there are no
practical difficulties and few inhibitions to be overcome. The definition of Supranationals
was, and remains, flexed enough.
So in bad market conditions, the “Draghi put” is real, in our view, and needs to be approached
with an active imagination. We make nothing of the “disappointment” in December, nor of
possible moves in the deposit rate. Not to be too dismissive, but our attention is strongly
elsewhere, on the quantum and the breadth of the Asset Purchase Programmes.
The situation is stabilized by those very observations; as we have seen in recent days, this
is a volatility-sapping situation as long as the ECB has credibility. We think it should,
despite December’s disappointment; Article 20 and a GC faced with existential risk are a
powerful combination. And when they (equals Draghi, in this situation, as discussed) all
but call the European credit markets out by name, as he did on 15 February2
, we need to
take notice. A measure of the extremes of sentiment in the week of 8 February was that
the ECB (and central banks generally) being "out of bullets" was a major theme.

PM

11:36 am
BE

FY15 results in line: LSE reported FY15 adjusted operating profit of £710m,
in line with CSe/company consensus of £708m. No surprises in the mix with
revenues and costs both broadly consistent with expectations. Total income
of £2,382m is 0-1% light of CSe/consensus (£2,412m /£2,389m) but costs of
£1,672m are 1-2% lower than CSe/consensus (£1,703m /£1,681m).
Adjusted EPS of 129.4p is 4% ahead of CSe (124.0p) consensus (124.7p),
driven by a slightly lower tax rate and minority interests.

BE

■ Dividend ahead: The company has declared a full year DPS of 36.0p, 8%
ahead of consensus of 33.2p (CSe 33.0p). Management intends to move
towards a 2.5-3.0x cover range which implies a modest increase in the yield
from 1% currently to 2% over the next couple of years at current prices.
■ No new news on DB1 merger: There is no new news on the proposed
merger with DB1, with discussions ongoing. We see attractive cost synergy
potential but expect the deal to be subject to intense antitrust scrutiny given
that it potentially raises barriers to entry in derivatives clearing at a time
when MIFID2 is attempting to inject more competition into the European
market.
■ CS view: We have a standalone valuation for LSE of 2,900p per share,
which is broadly where the stock trades, but we see a potential deal with
DB1 potentially adding 440p to this, assuming cost synergies equivalent to
15% of the combined expense base (but not including any revenue
synergies). There also remains the possibility of a superior counterbid from
ICE given that the company has confirmed that is considering an offer.

BE

11:43 am
BE

Net sales like-for-like growth of 3.3% was ahead of DBe 3.2% and consensus 3.0%. Growth in the 4Q was strong at 4.9%, in line with our estimates and an acceleration on previous quarters. FY15 Net sales of £10,524 and Adj. Op. profit of £1,774 were very slightly light vs. DBe £10,569 £1,802, but broadly in-line with consensus of £10,517 £1784. EPS of 93.6p was 3p/6p ahead of DBe / cons. Dividend of 44.7p also broadly in line with our 44.3p estimate and representing a payout ratio of 47.7%. Net debt of £3.56bn was ahead of our estimate of £3.2bn but more in line with our 2016 est. of £3.67bn. WPP should hold debt level for 2016, despite currency.

BE

January net sales were up 2.3%, ahead of budget and against a tough comp. January 2015 was up 3.9% whereas 1Q 2015 was up only 2.5% and April 15 was up 1.7%, so comps get easier in the coming months. Outlook is for 2016 net sales growth of over 3% and 30bp margin improvement at constant FX vs. DBe 3.3% net sales and 30 bp margin improvement.

BE

With 55% of the business from US and Europe, FX should move to become a positive for 2016 reported numbers, having been a headwind in 2015. FX at current exchange rates should add c.3% to net sales. This combined with organic growth outlook and acquisitions adding other 2-3% would result in reported growth of c.8% at the net sales level. We expect this FX to tailwind to add c.3% to consensus EPS for 2016.

11:43 am
BE

Advertising & Data, Investment Management were slightly below our estimates, with advertising organic growth of 3.8% vs. our estimate of 4.5%. Company pointed to a “slightly weaker second half” in the media investment management businesses, “principally in the UK”.

BE

North America continues to be strong at 4.1% u/y net sales growth. In the UK the rate of growth slowed in the 4Q. For the FY15 net sales were up 2.9% underlying. W. Continental Europe is “patchy” with Germany and Italy showing “good growth” but France and Spain (among others) were tougher. Surprisingly Latam was strong. Like-for-like net sales grew 7.1% in 4Q, the highest quarterly growth in 2015.
Buy, TP GBp 1,580
WPP is trading on 15.5x 2016 PE, 11x EV/EBITDA and 6.5% FCF yield. We see WPP as a GARP opportunity, delivering solid earnings growth with ac.5% yield from combined dividend + buy backs.

BE

Here's the cover page.

BE

The recent financial results for BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto marked a sea change, with both companies forsaking their progressive dividends for more flexible policies. Together with ongoing capex and cost reductions, this leaves the companies in significantly improved financial positions, allowing ongoing cash build - even under our assumption of a prolonged “disincentive pricing” environment.
Both companies are implementing material changes that have a profound impact on their forward cash flows. The new dividend policies could save BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto approximately $4.2bn/pa and $2.2bn/pa respectively, their FY16-17E total capex has been guided down $3.5bn and $3.0bn respectively, while both are targeting operating cost savings around $1bn/pa this year. Having already spun-off or sold most of their non-core operations, their asset bases are resilient and cash generative.

BE

We have adjusted our financial assumptions for the two companies to take into account the revised capex guidance and cost saving targets. We have, however, maintained our cash-flow-dependent dividend forecasts, which assume pay-out of 20-30% of sustainable operating cash flows. In our view, this better reflects, likely returns, given the likely variability from the prescribed dividend ratios and the underlying inference that the dividends will be contingent on available cash resources. Both companies should generate ample cashflow to cover dividends, with BHP Billiton rising to near 3x dividend cover by the end of the decade, with Rio Tinto at 2.0-2.5x.
Such pay-outs should enable the companies to deliver minimum dividend yields in the range of 3.2% to 4.2% (BHP Billiton) and 2.0% to 3.1% (Rio Tinto) at current equity prices, with discretion for additional shareholder returns from anticipated surplus cashflow, post capital expenditure and basic dividends. This surplus is expected to prove substantial, given the robust operating platforms that are now in place. We forecast $17bn surplus cash for BHP Billiton by the end of the decade and $5bn for Rio Tinto. Flat spot prices yield less difference between the two companies: the surplus is $13bn for BHP Billiton and $11bn for Rio Tinto.
Our target prices for the companies are underpinned by our NPV valuations, using a 10% discount rate. Post the aforementioned adjustments our TP for Rio Tinto has increased from 1859p to 2235p (+20%) and we retain a Buy recommendation. Our TP for BHP Billiton has increased 25%, from 591p to 739p, but given recent share price appreciation, we maintain a Sell recommendation. The material changes to valuations reflect the impact of stripping out another c.$1bn/pa of costs and reducing capex by several $bn. As margins get thinner, such changes become more pronounced.

Cineworld Group PLC (CINE:LSE): Last: 504.50, down 27.5 (-5.17%), High: 523.50, Low: 498.10, Volume: 304.76k
BE

UBS selling.

BE

We initiate coverage with a Sell rating and 490p price target. We are cautious on the
remaining growth opportunity in Central Eastern Europe, given the roll-out focus on
Romania which accounts for just 9% of screens, and signs of maturity elsewhere in the
region. In our view, 2015 was an exceptional year for the film slate and new openings,
but we now see a more limited long-term growth opportunity. We forecast a 5.5%
2015-18 revenue CAGR, and a 7.0% adj. EPS CAGR, driven by our below-consensus
forecasts for cinema roll-out and same-cinema sales growth.

12:03 pm
BE

Potential risk to roll-out strategy in CEE
CCE is a roll-out story, with growth predominantly driven by new screen additions. We
see risks to growth that make us more cautious on this opportunity; (1) the roll-out is
not evenly distributed, with Romania accounting for two-thirds of the new screen
pipeline, and whilst underpenetrated would have more screens per urban capita than
Poland if Cineworld opened their signed pipeline for 2016/17 (2) a 25% decline in
Polish revenues between 2009 and 2014 is a sobering reminder that an
underpenetrated market does not guarantee growth, (3) Romania pipeline risk given
the reliance on the real estate market to provide new site opportunities, (4) relatively
immature local film markets in some CEE regions, (5) declining population trends in
Poland, Romania and Hungary.
Weaker film slate and limited price optimisation to drive UK business
In the near term, we believe the 2016 film slate will disappoint, against a strong 2015.
The 2016 slate looks skewed towards children's titles, which we believe will have an
impact on average ticket price, and a lack of blockbusters and franchises with a strong
track record may act as a drag on admissions growth. We also believe Cineworld is
missing an opportunity in its UK business to optimise pricing on blockbusters: its prices
were on average 16% lower than Odeon and Vue's for the recent Star Wars release.
Valuation: Our 490p target price is based on a FY16E PE of 16.4x
We value Cineworld based on a DCF, assuming a WACC of 8.0% and a long-term
growth rate of 1.5%. On a relative multiple basis, our 490p price target implies a FY16
PE of 16.4x and PEG ratio of 2.5x, versus a peer PEG average of 1.7x.
